courses.name: Introduction to Drama, Theatre and Performance Studies

cmCourseInfo.description: A broad introduction to the canon of Western drama, the principles of theatre history as well as key artistic movements and notions of arts criticism through a range of dramatic texts, artistic movements, and performance practices, with particular reference to the relationship between dramatic texts and their larger contexts. This course combines weekly two-hour lectures with one-hour tutorials.
cmCourseInfo.title: Introduction to Drama, Theatre and Performance Studies
cmCourseInfo.exclusionsText: DRM100Y1, DRE121H5, DRE122H5, VPDA10H3, VPDA11H3, VPDA10H3, VPDA15H3, VPDB10H3, VPDB11H3

notes.name: Course Note
notes.content:
Timetable Instructions
Students must sign up for a tutorial. They will be informed of their tutorial room in the first week of class.

cmCourseInfo.description: Emphasis is initially placed on ensemble, non-verbal, and improvisational work. Students proceed to the application of their acquired skills to scripted material. Students may apply in their first or second year of University. The Application Deadline is March 10th for the first round of auditions; August 10th for the second round. Please consult the CDTPS undergraduate web page for information on how to apply.
cmCourseInfo.title: Performance I
cmCourseInfo.prerequisitesText: An audition in April or in August. Newly admitted students can apply for an audition before beginning their first year of studies.
cmCourseInfo.exclusionsText: DRS221H5 AND DRS222H5; VPDB01H3 AND VPDB02H3

notes.name: Course Note
notes.content:
Timetable Instructions
Selection is based on an audition & interview. Priority is reserved for Drama Majors and Specialists. First round of applications were due March 10th for auditions & interviews held in April. The second round of applications are due by August 10th and auditions & interviews will be held in late August. Students can apply straight out of high school: https://drama-apply.chass.utoronto.ca/login For more information, please contact Colleen Osborn at c.osborn@utoronto.ca

cmCourseInfo.description: An introduction to major concepts and artistic practices in directing, emphasizing theoretical and historical issues with supplemental practical application. The course focuses on different styles, ideas, and goals of theatre directors in their relations to actors, audiences, and broad cultural and political contexts. The Application Form Deadline is March 10th for the first round of interviews; August 10th for the second round. Please consult the CDTPS undergraduate web page for information on how to apply.
cmCourseInfo.title: Directing I
cmCourseInfo.prerequisitesText: An interview in April or in August with a letter of interest. Newly admitted students can apply for an interview before beginning their first year of studies.
cmCourseInfo.recommendedPreparation:
DRM100Y1/DRM101Y1/UNI102Y1

Distribution Requirement: Humanities

Breadth Requirement: Creative and Cultural Representations (1)

notes.name: Course Note
notes.content:
Timetable Instructions
Selection is based on an application and interview. Priority is given to Drama Majors and Specialists. Apply online: https://drama-apply.chass.utoronto.ca/login For more information, please contact Colleen Osborn at c.osborn@utoronto.ca.

cmCourseInfo.description: An intensive study of a range of historical and cross-cultural dramatic and performance texts and practices that contextualize theatre and performance more broadly within the social, political, and cultural parameters in which they take place. Theatre history is necessarily inextricable from world history and this course considers the many ways theatre and performance interact with the globalized world.
cmCourseInfo.title: Comparative Theatre Histories
cmCourseInfo.prerequisitesText: DRM100Y1/DRM101Y1/(UNI102H1, UNI106H1)/UNI102Y1

cmCourseInfo.description: A hands-on study of the craft of dramatic writing. The class examines the basic elements of playwriting such as plot, structure, theme, character, dialogue, setting, with an emphasis on story-making. Attention is given to the development of students own work through written assignments and in-class exercises. The Application Deadline is March 10th for the first round; August 10th for the second round. Please consult the CDTPS undergraduate web page for information on how to apply.
cmCourseInfo.title: Playwriting I
cmCourseInfo.prerequisitesText: A portfolio of writing samples due on March 10th or August 10th. Newly admitted students can submit their portfolio of writing samples before beginning their first year of studies.

cmCourseInfo.description: An introduction to the shifting landscapes of European theatre theory, history and practice in the late 19th century and their repercussions throughout the 20th and 21st centuries. The course focuses on the developments of modern and postdramatic theatre. It also includes critical analysis of the annual Drama Mainstage production and current Canadian theatre.
cmCourseInfo.title: Concepts of Twentieth-Century Theatre
cmCourseInfo.prerequisitesText: DRM100Y1/DRM101Y1/(UNI102H1, UNI106H1)/UNI102Y1

cmCourseInfo.description: A practical and theoretical introduction to the fundamentals of theatrical performance design. This course touches on theatre architecture, conceptual approaches to theatrical design and spatial considerations of live performance. Students will work on case studies and practical projects geared toward understanding theatre terminology, design, and production processes. Students will also explore concrete aspects of technical theatre production, particularly as they pertain to theatrical design elements. Applications are required in order to enroll in this course. First-round applications are due in March, and second-round applications are due in August. Please consult the CDTPS Application Guidelines for specific procedures and deadlines.
cmCourseInfo.title: Design and Production I
cmCourseInfo.prerequisitesText: An interview in April or in August. Newly admitted students can apply for an interview before beginning their first year of studies.

notes.name: Course Note
notes.content:
Timetable Instructions
Selection is based on an interview. Priority is reserved for Drama Majors and Specialists. The first round of applications were due March 10th for interviews held in April. The second round of applications are due by August 10th and interviews will be held in late August. Students can apply straight out of high school: https://drama-apply.chass.utoronto.ca/login For more information, please contact Colleen Osborn at c.osborn@utoronto.ca

notes.name: Section Note
notes.content: Wednesday Rooms Updated: November 26, 2019.

cmCourseInfo.description: Building upon the work of DRM200Y1, students concentrate on scene study, styles of acting, and the development of ensemble work with an intensive focus on voice and movement practices. The Application Deadline is March 10th.
cmCourseInfo.title: Performance II
cmCourseInfo.prerequisitesText: Minimum 70% in required courses: DRM100Y1/DRM101Y1/(UNI102H1, UNI106H1)/UNI102Y1; DRM200Y1; and permission of the Centre.
cmCourseInfo.corequisitesText: DRM220Y1/DRM230Y1 or any course from Group A if DRM220Y1/DRM230Y1 is complete; 0.5 FCE from DRM375H1/DRM376H1/DRM377H1/DRM378H1 or permission of the Centre.
cmCourseInfo.recommendedPreparation: and the development of ensemble work with an intensive focus on voice and movement practices. The

notes.name: Course Note
notes.content:
Timetable Instructions
For more information on how to enrol, please contact Colleen Osborn at c.osborn@utoronto.ca.

cmCourseInfo.description: A continuation of DRM202H1, concentrating on major concepts and artistic practices in directing. The course focuses on different styles, ideas, and goals of theatre directors in their relations to actors, audiences, and broad cultural and political contexts. A major component will be the practical application of basic directing techniques. Please consult the CDTPS undergraduate web page for information on how to apply and the deadline to apply.
cmCourseInfo.title: Directing II
cmCourseInfo.prerequisitesText: Minimum 70% in required courses: DRM100Y1/DRM101Y1/(UNI102H1, UNI106H1)/UNI102Y1; DRM202H1; and permission of the Centre.
cmCourseInfo.corequisitesText: DRM220Y1/DRM230Y1 or any course from Group A.

notes.name: Course Note
notes.content:
Timetable Instructions
Selection is based on an application. Priority is given to Drama Majors and Specialists. Apply online by November 10th. https://drama-apply.chass.utoronto.ca/login For more information, please contact Colleen Osborn at c.osborn@utoronto.ca

cmCourseInfo.description: A continuation of DRM228H1, concentrating on the in-depth knowledge and practice of playwriting with an emphasis on style and technique of writing for the stage. Students develop their own work through written assignments, in-class exercises, and the final public presentation. Please consult the CDTPS undergraduate web page for information on how to apply and the deadline to apply.
cmCourseInfo.title: Playwriting II
cmCourseInfo.prerequisitesText: Minimum 70% in required courses: DRM100Y1/DRM101Y1/(UNI102H1, UNI106H1)/UNI102Y1; DRM228H1; and permission of the Centre.
cmCourseInfo.corequisitesText: DRM220Y1/DRM230Y1 or any course from Group A

notes.name: Course Note
notes.content:
Timetable Instructions
Selection is based on a portfolio submission. Priority is reserved for Drama Majors and Specialists. The first round of applications were due March 10th. The second round of applications are due by August 10th: https://drama-apply.chass.utoronto.ca/login

cmCourseInfo.description: Study of dramaturgical theory and of interpretations of the dramaturge's function in the theatre. Using examples from Canada and beyond, students apply this knowledge to theatre practice.
cmCourseInfo.title: Dramaturgy
cmCourseInfo.prerequisitesText: DRM100Y1/DRM101Y1/(UNI102H1, UNI106H1)/UNI102Y1

cmCourseInfo.description: An intermediate-level investigation of various aspects of theatrical performance design, with a focus on scenic and costume design, though also considering the impact of projections and lighting. Using skills developed through practical study in the Design Studio, the students form the core of the design team for Drama productions. Applications are required in order to enroll in this course. Please consult the CDTPS Application Guidelines for specific procedures and deadlines.
cmCourseInfo.title: Design II
cmCourseInfo.prerequisitesText: Minimum 70% in required courses: DRM100Y1/DRM101Y1/(UNI102H1, UNI106H1)/UNI102Y1; DRM254H1/DRM254Y1; and permission of the Centre.
cmCourseInfo.corequisitesText: DRM220Y1/DRM230Y1 or any course from Group A

cmCourseInfo.description: An intermediate-level investigation of various aspects of theatrical production, including stage management, lighting, sound and video, with some exploration of how these elements relate to theatrical design concepts. Using skills developed through practical study in the Helen Gardiner Phelan Playhouse, the students form the core of the production team for Drama productions. Applications are required in order to enroll in this course. Please consult the CDTPS Guidelines for specific procedures and deadlines.
cmCourseInfo.title: Production II
cmCourseInfo.prerequisitesText: Minimum 70% in required courses: DRM100Y1/DRM101Y1/(UNI102H1, UNI106H1)/UNI102Y1; DRM254H1/DRM254Y1; or permission of the Centre.
cmCourseInfo.corequisitesText: DRM220Y1/DRM230Y1 or any course from Group A

cmCourseInfo.description: Since the 1960s, actors, directors, and writers have been architects of Canadian identity. This course will study the history of Canadian theatre, with an emphasis on how Canadian playwrights and creators have been engaged with social and political issues. A survey of post-colonial theatre, cultural diversity, and gender politics on the Canadian stage.
cmCourseInfo.title: Canadian Theatre
cmCourseInfo.prerequisitesText: DRM100Y1/DRM101Y1/UNI102Y1 or any 4.0 FCE
cmCourseInfo.recommendedPreparation: For Drama Majors and Specialists: DRM220Y1/DRM230Y1

cmCourseInfo.description: An in-depth study of devising theatre in a group context. This course offers an intensive exploration of the history and practice of devised theatre within the late 20th and early 21st centuries that will culminate in a number of in-class and public performances.
cmCourseInfo.title: Devised Theatre
cmCourseInfo.prerequisitesText: Minimum 70% in required courses: DRM100Y1/DRM101Y1/(UNI102H1, UNI106H1)/UNI102Y1; DRM200Y1 or permission of the Drama Centre.

notes.name: Course Note
notes.content:
Timetable Instructions
To enroll in DRM368H1, you must take DRM300Y1 as a pre or co-requisite. DRM300Y1 students must meet the pre-reqs and apply by March 10th online: https://drama-apply.chass.utoronto.ca/login For more information, please contact Colleen Osborn at c.osborn@utoronto.ca

cmCourseInfo.description: An in-depth examination of selected performance disciplines, styles, and genres within their historical and critical context. Content may vary depending on instructor. Please check Studio Topics on the CDTPS undergraduate web page for more details.
cmCourseInfo.title: Special Topics in Studio Practice
cmCourseInfo.prerequisitesText: Minimum 70% in required courses: DRM100Y1/DRM101Y1/(UNI102H1, UNI106H1)/UNI102Y1; DRM200Y1; or permission of the Centre.
cmCourseInfo.corequisitesText: DRM300Y1 or permission of the Centre.

courses.name: Independent Studies in Drama, Theatre and Performance Studies

cmCourseInfo.description: A scholarly project at the 300 level proposed by the individual student in conversation with a member of faculty who is willing to act as supervisor. Not eligible for CR/NCR option.
cmCourseInfo.title: Independent Studies in Drama, Theatre and Performance Studies
cmCourseInfo.prerequisitesText: Minimum 70% in DRM220Y1/DRM230Y1; 10 FCE; Specialist or Major in Drama; A written proposal; Independent study form signed by both student and faculty instructor to be submitted for approval to the Associate Director (undergraduate) before registration: August 1st for September start date; November 1st for January start date.

notes.name: Course Note
notes.content:
Timetable Instructions
A written proposal; Independent study form to be submitted for approval to the Associate Director (undergraduate) by August 1st for a September start date. For more information, please contact Colleen Osborn at c.osborn@utoronto.ca.

cmCourseInfo.description: Advanced Performance builds on the training sequence of DRM200Y1 and DRM300Y1 by developing students’ acting and performance skills in monologues, extensive collaborative scene work, and preparations for auditions. The work focuses on the particulars of character development and the emotional and technical aspects of the actor’s craft. Applications are required in order to enroll in this course. Please consult the CDTPS Application Guidelines for specific procedures and deadlines.
cmCourseInfo.title: Advanced Performance
cmCourseInfo.prerequisitesText: Specialist or Major in Drama; Minimum 70% in required courses: DRM220Y1/DRM230Y1; DRM300Y1; and permission of the Centre.

cmCourseInfo.description: An exploration of advanced directing for the theatre. The class is centered on student directed productions, which are publically presented at the end of term. Emphasis is placed on the development of strong central concepts and realizing the production with imagination, collaboration and creativity. Please consult the CDTPS Application Guidelines for specific procedures and deadlines.
cmCourseInfo.title: Advanced Directing
cmCourseInfo.prerequisitesText: Specialist or Major in Drama; Minimum 70% in required courses: DRM220Y1/DRM230Y1; DRM302H1; DRM331H1; a written proposal and an interview in April.

notes.name: Course Note
notes.content:
Timetable Instructions
Applications are due on March 10th preceding each academic year. Please apply online: https://drama-apply.chass.utoronto.ca/login There will be additional tutorial times which will be held regularly. Dates and times to be determined based on student availability. For more information, please contact Colleen Osborn at c.osborn@utoronto.ca.

cmCourseInfo.description: This course, taught each year by a different visiting professional theatre director, offers upper-level theatre and performance studies students the opportunity to explore acting in a full-length production. Plays are selected to challenge students in a variety of diverse ways, exposing them to a full spectrum of theatre and performance genres and possibilities. Applications are required in order to enroll in this course. Please consult the CDTPS Application Guidelines for specific procedures and deadlines.
cmCourseInfo.title: Mainstage Performance
cmCourseInfo.prerequisitesText: Specialist or Major in Drama; Minimum 70% in required courses: DRM220Y1/DRM230Y1; DRM300Y1, 0.5 FCE from DRM368H1/DRM375H1/DRM376H1/DRM377H1/DRM378H1; and permission of the Centre.
cmCourseInfo.corequisitesText: DRM400H1, DRM413H1 (or permission of the Centre).

notes.name: Course Note
notes.content:
Timetable Instructions
Applications are due on March 10th preceding each academic year. Please apply online using the link: https://drama-apply.chass.utoronto.ca/login There will be additional tutorial times which will be held regularly in the second term. Dates and times to be determined based on student availability. For more information, please contact Colleen Osborn at c.osborn@utoronto.ca.

cmCourseInfo.description: Voice and Movement is a skill-developing companion to the DRM400 training for performers. It exposes students to a wide range of voice and movement techniques and explores a heightened use of physicality, voice and speech.
cmCourseInfo.title: Advanced Voice and Movement
cmCourseInfo.prerequisitesText: Minimum 70% in required courses: DRM220Y1/ DRM230Y1; DRM300Y1; acceptance into DRM403Y1 or permission of the Centre
cmCourseInfo.corequisitesText: DRM403Y1 or permission of the Centre

cmCourseInfo.description: A continuation of DRM328H1, concentrating upon the in-depth knowledge and practice of playwriting with an emphasis on advanced style and technique of writing for the stage. Students develop their own longer work through in-class exercises, one major written assignment, and the final public presentation. Please consult the CDTPS undergraduate web page for information on how to apply.
cmCourseInfo.title: Advanced Playwriting
cmCourseInfo.prerequisitesText: Minimum 70% in required courses: DRM220Y1/DRM230Y1, DRM328H1 and a portfolio of writing samples due in November.

notes.name: Course Note
notes.content:
Timetable Instructions
Selection is based on an portfolio submission. Apply online by November 10th. https://drama-apply.chass.utoronto.ca/login There will be additional tutorial times which will be held regularly. Dates and times to be determined based on student availability. For more information, please contact Colleen Osborn at c.osborn@utoronto.ca.

cmCourseInfo.description: An advanced-level exploration of theatrical design skills and techniques, delving deeper into specific areas of specialization and with more opportunity for independent work. Students are expected to participate in Drama Centre productions in senior creative and leadership roles. Applications are required in order to enroll in this course. Please consult the CDTPS Application Guidelines for specific procedures and deadlines.
cmCourseInfo.title: Advanced Design
cmCourseInfo.prerequisitesText: Minimum 70% in required courses: DRM220Y1/DRM230Y1;  DRM354H1/DRM354Y1

cmCourseInfo.description: An advanced-level exploration of production skills and techniques, delving deeper into specific areas of specialization and with more opportunity for independent work. Students are expected to participate in Drama Centre productions in senior creative and leadership roles. Applications are required in order to enroll in this course. Please consult the CDTPS Application Guidelines for specific procedures and deadlines.
cmCourseInfo.title: Advanced Production
cmCourseInfo.prerequisitesText: Minimum CGPA of 2.7; DRM220Y1/ DRM230Y1; DRM355Y1; and permission of the Drama Centre.

courses.name: Senior Seminar in Drama, Theatre and Performance Studies

cmCourseInfo.description: An in-depth examination of selected issues in the theatre at the 400 level. Special Topics vary for Breadth distribution depending on the course content and therefore may be counted towards Groups A or B. Please consult the Undergraduate Drama office or check the program’s website for more details.
cmCourseInfo.title: Senior Seminar in Drama, Theatre and Performance Studies
cmCourseInfo.prerequisitesText: Specialist or Major in Drama; 14 FCE; DRM220Y1/DRM230Y1; and/or permission of the Centre.
